newsitem.title: USA: Oxy resumes Cao Limn output, liftings delayed.
newsitem.headline: Oxy resumes Cao Limn output, liftings delayed.

text.p: Occidental Petroleum Corp resumed normal operations at the Cao Limn oil field in Colombia following back-to-back rebel bombings of the Cao Limn-Coveas pipeline, although liftings are expected to be delayed by one to two days, company and trade sources said on Thursday.
"Repairs have been made, force majeur has been lifted and production has resumed," an Oxy spokesman said.
Occidental, which operates the 215,000 barrels per day (bpd) field, was forced to temporarily shut in output after Tuesday's blast, the second in a week.
Colombia's state oil company Ecopetrol operates the pipeline, which transports 200,000 bpd of crude from Cao Limn in northeast Arauca province to the Caribbean port of Coveas.
Two crude tankers that had been unable to load at Coveas have also resumed normal operations, trade sources said.
The two Panamax tankers are the Santa Panaglia, which is bound for Peru on behalf of Spain's Repsol and the Harrier, which is bound for the United States for Shell Oil Co .
As a result of the shut-in, however, Ecopetrol was expected late on Thursday to issue a new lifting schedule, reflecting delays of one to two days.
In all, the pipeline has been blown up 34 times so far this year.
All of the attacks are thought to be the work of National Lioberation Army (ELN) rebels, who dynamited the pipeline 47 times last year and spilled more than 105,000 barrels of crude.
